displayed_text: Family Member: Oh, yeah, yes, yes. Right? Doctor: You just being bent over and not looking at anything but the floor. Family Member: Right. Doctor: This is great. Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: And you’re making music again? Family Member: Right. Patient: I am, totally. Doctor: I mean, that, you know? Patient: I’m having fun. Doctor: That’s a scale. I mean that’s amazing. Wow. When you’re talented, you’re talented. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: And there’s nothing like cancer that’s going to stop you.

Patient: We’ll reevaluate. We’ll take a look at it, you understand? Doctor: Yes. Patient: Maybe in October or December – Doctor: Okay. Patient: Of next year. Doctor: Mr. L_, I know from talking with you the last time. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: You were not keen on getting cut open or getting your bowels or your pee’s re-routed. Patient: I’m really not. Doctor: I know you’re not. Patient: I mean, and they want me to put the bag on. Doctor: I know they do.

Patient: Right. Doctor: We had the bone scan and you had both of those areas radiated at the same time as getting the hormone therapy. Patient: Correct. Right. Doctor: So it’s possible that those would not be visible at this time. Or it’s possible that they still might be visible and it’s also possible that new areas you know might have popped up somewhere else in different bones or different areas like lymph nodes which were not there before. So it’s very important you know once the PSA reaches one that we basically establish what the extent of your cancer is at that point in time. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay, um, the standard recommendation for you at that point would be to go back uh on a hormone therapy. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: And my recommendation to do that would be a little bit stronger if the cancer is visible – Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: - on the scan, especially if it has progressed. And the recommendation would be weaker; in other words, I would be open to delaying the hormone therapy a bit longer if the cancer cannot be seen. Patient: Okay. Doctor: In other words if it’s just the PSA rising and the absence of any visible cancer on the scan. Patient: At what point would you do the scan? Is it when it goes above one?

Patient: Okay. Doctor: All that sugar stuff, all the rocket fuel—it’s all myth. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: Right, it’s all myth. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And you know you can eat red meat once a week. You can drink you know in moderation. Do not ruin - you know it’s all myth, right. People feel very strongly about those myths. Patient: Right. Doctor: It’s all myth. The key is stay in shape. Patient: Right. Yeah, that’s the easy for me. Doctor: That’s it. Patient: Okay, well I’ll definitely - Family Member: Well gosh; we may want to eat more than lettuce tonight. Patient: Right. I don’t have to be a rabbit anymore? We might have to change this little tail that I’m growing.

Patient: Right. Doctor: that way I know when you started. When you’ve been on it for two or three weeks, you come back to see me and we’ll make sure you’re doing okay. Patient: When I’m doing okay. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: So now okay you know what my next question is… Doctor: Yeah. Patient: You know I got that motorcycle. Doctor: I know. Family Member: Please stop. Didn’t I tell you to stay off that motorcycle? Patient: You didn’t tell me to stay off my motorcycle. Family Member: From the last time we were here, I’ve told him to stop being on that motorcycle. Doctor: Well we worry about you being on that motorcycle. You know that. I know it’s what you love. You love being on that motorcycle but I worry about the way your back is and all this stuff. I just worry about it. Patient: Okay. Okay so here’s the deal.

Patient: Okay. Okay. Doctor: So I was hoping at that point if we have some answers for you we can even get… Family Member: Mm, even get started. Doctor: … start anticipating and making some decisions about the other thing. Okay? Family Member: Okay. Patient: That’ll work. Doctor: So I was gonna say you should sign the pre-screening consent if that’s okay with you and send the blood test out. Patient: Sure. Doctor: And that doesn’t commit us to absolutely do this study or… Patient: Yeah. Right. Family Member: It gets the ball rolling. Doctor: Correct. Exactly. And finding out that information is useful anyway even down the road. Even if you don’t do this particular study. Patient: Yeah, yeah, yeah. More information is always better.

Family Member: Mm Hmm. Doctor: So we don’t, I don’t think that’s part of their indication. Um, but, you know, we’d have to ask the proton guys for that. Family Member: Yeah. Patient: Well then being that the radiation is site specific Doctor: Mm Mmm. Patient: and you’ve created this area- Doctor: Yep. Patient: Why wouldn’t we go site specific in all the other areas that I have- Family Member: You don’t want too much. Too much will kill ya’. Patient: -that you have imaging to know where it is? Doctor: Well, because it doesn’t change the outcome. So your treatment is so that the pain gets better as in kill the cells, no pain. If you have pain elsewhere, you could consider that. But if it’s just a pluck off the areas that you think has cancer, it doesn’t change the overall status of your disease. You know? You don’t live longer with it but you might get some down sides. You know? Like she said the more you radiate the more your bone marrow is hit. So you’ll get a consequence off of that where you might lose some cells. Family Member: Mm Hmm. Doctor: So you don’t want to treat them unless you know what you’re going to get a result of. So with radiation right now the result is gee I hope my pain is controlled. That’s what I wanted for you. The second one would be gee I hope my pain is controlled and my spine gets stabilized. Whew. And then number three would be I hope the cancer doesn’t come back there. You know? Now it’s been burned out.

Patient: I’m not one. Doctor: Yeah. Exactly. Patient: It’s amazing uh well one thing I’m really fortunate with is that um I’m at a state of mind where I just that kind of helps me when I’m making decisions. So it’s not like Doctor: is that cancer care has become so expensive. Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: companies charge for their services Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: -and for that immunotherapy six hundred thousand dollars. So Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: We’re trying not to let the insurance companies … for a different indication and insurance companies… Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: you have five FDA approved therapies. (xx)

Patient: Alright. Doctor: Well thank you both for participating. I think you know I think we’ve very appreciative that you know- Patient: Well I hope we learned, we learned something. Maybe. Maybe not. Doctor: Well, you know, it’s a crazy thing to try. So you know it’s not the typical patient that says yeah, I’m, I’m fine. I really appreciate your involvement. Hopefully we’ve got a lot more stuff we can do here. Patient: Yes. Doctor: Okay? Patient: Alright. Appreciate it. Doctor: Safe travels. Patient: Same to you. Doctor: Are you going back to F___? Patient: We are, later today. Doctor: Snow in N__, really crazy?

Patient: So let me ask you this here because we talked about this in case it didn’t work. Doctor: Yes we did. Patient: Okay. Let me ask you this here. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: So when when when can we start taking the pill? Doctor: So what happens is I go through the insurance. They go through a third party vendor. So Diplomate, CVS Caremark, whatever one your insurance you know sends me to. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Then they mail it to your house Patient: Okay. Doctor: and then when you get it you take four pills a day. Patient: Mm, Hmm. Doctor: If you can, you just call us, call K__ or W__ and go hey we got the medicine Patient: Right.

Healthcare Professional: So quit climbing ladders and falling. Doctor: That’s – I was going to do a drive-by and get his stinking ladder. Healthcare Professional: Yeah. Doctor: Let her shoot you up, my friend. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay, I’m going to get this rolling with Dr. ___. Patient: So it seems to me though that - Doctor: Yeah? Patient: I come off the Xtandi now; I’m not having, I’m not taking anything to treat the cancer. Doctor: Yeah, right, until you get to the next one, which is this radium or Xofigo. It starts with another “X” name. So don’t get confused. So it’s not Xtandi; it’s Xofigo. Patient: But it would seem to me it makes more sense to keep taking Xtandi till I’m on that treatment. Doctor: You would think so but your cancer has figured it out. (pause) Family Member: So could it start like the first of January and then -

Patient: And you’d maintain the care? Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: That’s very important. Patient: Okay and uh okay. Yeah we’ll look at the consent form. It sounds more complicated. Doctor: Because one side, yeah so there is – I think what I’ll do is I’ll give you the consent to read through and then we’ll set up a time to come in downtown with the potential for doing all the testing needed if you decide you’re okay with proceeding. Patient: And we were planning to go on a cruise in February. Doctor: Okay. That should be fine still. Patient: Really? Doctor: Yeah. I don’t see any reason to cancel that. Family Member: Unless you want to – so it doesn’t matter whether we sign the consent today or that day to you. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: So when’s the next time I come in to I guess there? There’s no way of doing it here? Doctor: It’s too much.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.2 times: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::2 times

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.strongly agree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::strongly agree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.disagree: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::disagree

You completely trust doctors' decisions.neutral: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::neutral

A doctor would never mislead you about a.strongly disagree: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.::: strongly disagree

All in all, you trust doctors completely.neutral: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::neutral

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.neutral: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::neutral

People of my ethnic group are treated th.neutral: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::neutral

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.neutral: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::neutral

Which of the following best describe you.Employed: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Employed

What is the highest grade or level of s.College graduate: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::College graduate

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.Asian: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::Asian

displayed_text: Healthcare Professional: Yeah. We can get you started. Family Member: What are the pills? Doctor: Uh, the pills are bicalutamide. So, basically, they, uh, block, uh, your cancer cell from using testosterone that’s in your body. So, right away, they start treating your cancer. Uh. But, when I give you your shot, uh, the testosterone shoots up. It could make your cancer worse in that few days. And, so, I wanna protect that surge of testosterone that occurs when we give you the first shot. Patient: Hmmm. Family Member: The first shot of the hormone? Doctor: The first shot of the hormones. Patient: The body reacts- Family Member: Why would it do that? Doctor: Uh, because basically the medicine is, uh, a protein your body makes and just fools the brain into thinking that there’s too much testosterone, uh, and sort of tells the testicles, “Stop making testosterone.” But that which is there gets released. Family Member: Ahhh. Doctor: And so you just get a surge. And so, Family Member: Ahh.

Patient: As a preemptive strike? Doctor: Correct. Patient: Oh. Doctor: As a preemptive strike kind of to mop up any residual- Patient: Right. Doctor: -cancer that may be remaining or viable within the field. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay? Healthcare Professional: You need to have another (talking over each other) Doctor: Yeah and you need to have it as G____ just pointed out, you need to have an undetectable PSA. Healthcare Professional: Which he has. Doctor: Which you have. Patient: Okay.

Family Member: Oh, oh, oh Doctor: But I think the way back when CAT scan you had some. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: Okay but they were very small and they may not be something at all significant. So you know I think your last CAT scan again barely showed anything Patient: Right. Doctor: so I don’t think we need to worry about those. But doing that Xofigo treatment would absolutely be another valid option if you don’t want to do chemotherapy. So the good news is that you have some options for standard treatment and you have some options for clinical trials. So you know either way we have options. I’m just reluctant to switch things if the scans don’t show us any change. Family Member 2: Right, right. Doctor: I mean then I think we should sort of say I don’t care what the PSA is doing but you’re doing great and the scans are looking fine. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: We just stay the course. Questions? Family Member: I just have one question. Doctor: Yes. Family Member: So from part one to part two the trial that he was on,
